revision.text:
A '''copyright transfer agreement''' is a legal document containing provisions for the conveyance of full or partial [[copyright]] from the rights owner to another party. It is similar to [[contract]]s signed between [[author]]s and [[publisher]]s but does not normally involve the payment of remuneration or [[royalties]].<ref name=Gadd2003-4>{{Cite journal | last1 = Gadd | first1 = E. | last2 = Oppenheim | first2 = C. | last3 = Probets | first3 = S. | doi = 10.1087/095315103322422053 | title = RoMEO studies 4: An analysis of journal publishers' copyright agreements | journal = Learned Publishing | volume = 16 | issue = 4 | pages = 293 | year = 2003 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> Such agreements are a key element of [[Subscription business model|subscription]]-based [[academic publishing]],<ref name=Friedman1982>{{Cite journal | last1 = Friedman | first1 = B. A. | title = Copyright from a permissions person's point of view | doi = 10.1021/ci00034a001 | journal = Journal of Chemical Information and Modeling | volume = 22 | issue = 2 | pages = 70–72 | year = 1982 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> and have been said to facilitate the handling of copyright-based permissions in print-only publishing.<ref name=Lagowski1982>{{Cite journal | last1 = Lagowski | first1 = J. | title = Journal Copyright Problems: An Editor's View | doi = 10.1021/ci00034a600 | journal = Journal of Chemical Information and Modeling | volume = 22 | issue = 2 | pages = 72–73 | year = 1982 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> In the age of electronic communication, the benefits of copyright transfer agreements have been questioned,<ref name=Bachrach1998>{{Cite journal | last1 = Bachrach | first1 = S. | last2 = Berry | first2 = R. S. | last3 = Blume | first3 = M. | last4 = Von Foerster | first4 = T. | last5 = Fowler | first5 = A. | last6 = Ginsparg | first6 = P. | last7 = Heller | first7 = S. | last8 = Kestner | first8 = N. | last9 = Odlyzko | first9 = A. | last10 = Okerson | first10 = A. | last11 = Wigington | first11 = R. | last12 = Moffat | first12 = A. | title = INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY:Who Should Own Scientific Papers? | doi = 10.1126/science.281.5382.1459 | journal = Science | volume = 281 | issue = 5382 | pages = 1459–1460 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9750115| pmc = }}</ref> and while they remain the norm, open [[license]]s as used in [[open access]] publishing have been established as an alternative.<ref name=Carroll2011>{{Cite journal | last1 = Carroll | first1 = M. W. | title = Why Full Open Access Matters | doi = 10.1371/journal.pbio.1001210 | journal = PLoS Biology | volume = 9 | issue = 11 | pages = e1001210 | year = 2011 | pmid = 22140361| pmc =3226455 }}</ref>
== History == Copyright transfer agreements became common in the publishing business after the [[Copyright Act of 1976]] in the United States and similar legislation in other countries<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1107/S0021889878012753 | title = Transfer of Copyright | journal = Journal of Applied Crystallography | volume = 11 | pages = 63–64 | year = 1978 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> redefined copyright as accruing to the author from the moment of creation (rather than publication) of a work.<ref name=Bachrach1998/> This required publishers to acquire copyrights from the author in order to sell the works or access to it, and written statements signed by the rights owner became necessary in order for the copyright transfer to be considered valid.<ref name=Friedman1982/><ref>[http://www.copyright.gov/title17/92chap2.html#204 Section 204] of the [[Copyright Act of 1976]]</ref>
== Purpose == {{Quotation|The situation in which authors hold the copyright usually involves considerable effort in the form of correspondence and record keeping and often leads to unnecessary delays. Although this may appear to be trivial for a few requests, a good scholarly journal publishing exciting papers can expect several hundred requests per year; a task of this magnitude can become onerous. On the other hand, if the Journal holds the copyright, requests, value judgements, and permissions can be handled expeditiously to the satisfaction of all concerned.|J. Lagowski (1982)<ref name=Lagowski1982/>}}
Granting publishers the permission to copy, display and distribute the work is necessary for publishers to act as such, and copyright transfer agreements across a wide range of publishers have such provisions.<ref name=Gadd2003-4/><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Gaeta | first1 = T. J. | title = Authorship: "Law" and Order | doi = 10.1111/j.1553-2712.1999.tb00393.x | journal = Academic Emergency Medicine | volume = 6 | issue = 4 | pages = 297–301 | year = 1999 | pmid = 10230981| pmc = }}</ref> The reach of copyright transfer agreements can go well beyond that, and "[s]ome publishers require that, to the extent possible, copyright be transferred to them."<ref name=Friedman1982/> This means that no one, including the authors, can reuse text, tables, or figures in other publications without first getting permission from the new copyright owner.<ref name="understand">{{Cite journal | last1 = Berquist | first1 = T. H. | title = The Copyright Transfer Agreement: We Sign It, but Do We Understand It? | doi = 10.2214/AJR.09.2655 | journal = American Journal of Roentgenology | volume = 192 | issue = 4 | pages = 849–851| year = 2009 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>
Copyright transfer agreements also ask that the authors confirm to actually own the copyright for all the materials pertaining to a given act of publishing, and that the item for which the copyright is to be transferred has not been previously published and is not under consideration to be published elsewhere,<ref name="understand"/> to limit the frequency of [[duplicate publication]] and [[plagiarism]].<ref name=Gadd2003-4/><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Lee | first1 = I. S. | last2 = Spector | first2 = M. | doi = 10.1088/1748-6041/7/1/010201 | title = Coping with copying and conflicts (of interest) | journal = Biomedical Materials | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | pages = 010201 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22287538| pmc = }}</ref>
== Criticisms == Critics have said that the copyright transfer agreement in commercial scholarly publishing is "as much about ensuring long–term asset management as it is about providing service to the academic community" because the practice seems to grant favor to the publisher in a way that does not obviously benefit the authors.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Willinsky|first=John|title=Copyright Contradictions in Scholarly Publishing|journal=[[First Monday (journal)|First Monday]]|date=4 November 2002|volume=7|issue=11|url=http://firstmonday.org/htbin/cgiwrap/bin/ojs/index.php/fm/article/view/1006/927|accessdate=20 February 2012|doi=10.5210/fm.v7i11.1006}}</ref> Copyright transfer agreements often conflict with [[self-archiving]] practices<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Gadd | first1 = E. | last2 = Oppenheim | first2 = C. | last3 = Probets | first3 = S. | doi = 10.1108/00220410310698239 | title = RoMEO studies 1: The impact of copyright ownership on academic author self-archiving | journal = Journal of Documentation | volume = 59 | issue = 3 | pages = 243 | year = 2003 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> or appear to do so due to ambiguous language.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Coleman | first1 = A. | title = Self-archiving and the Copyright Transfer Agreements of ISI-ranked library and information science journals | doi = 10.1002/asi.20494 | journal = Journal of the American Society for Information Science and Technology | volume = 58 | issue = 2 | pages = 286 | year = 2007 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>
In 2017, the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals in [https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=3767615587113113566&q=Storix&hl=en&as_sdt=6,29 Johnson v. Storix] upheld a copyright transfer involving no written assignment. In that case, the Author, Anthony Johnson sold software as a sole proprietor and incorporated his company in 2003 as Storix, Inc. Eight years later he gave 60% share of the corporation to his employees, who later removed him from the company and claimed ownership of the copyrights. The court upheld a jury decision that Johnson had made an oral agreement to transfer the copyright to the corporation upon its formation based on an annual report he wrote and signed a year later stating that he had transferred “all assets” from his sole proprietorship. The jury rejected Johnson's claim he intended only to transfer the license to sell the software, and further decided that Johnson became a work for hire upon forming the corporation, thereby also forfeiting all rights to his derivative works. This is the first case in which a document, not itself a contract or agreement and containing no reference to the copyrights, was considered a “note or memorandum” of copyright transfer, and the first time a sole owner of a company was designated a work for hire for copyright ownership purposes. This serves as a lesson that a “writing” required by the Copyright Act need not necessarily be “clear”, but may contain ambiguous language which can be interpreted by course of dealing by third parties to the alleged transaction.
== Other models == Copyright transfer agreements are one way to govern permissions based on copyright. Since the advent of digital publishing, various commentators have pointed out the benefits of author-retained copyright,<ref name=Bachrach1998/><ref name=Wilbanks2006>{{Cite journal | last1 = Wilbanks | first1 = J. | authorlink = John Wilbanks| title = Another reason for opening access to research | doi = 10.1136/sbmj.39063.730660.F7 | journal = BMJ | volume = 333 | issue = 7582 | pages = 1306–1308 | year = 2006 | pmid = 17185718 | pmc =1761190 }}</ref> and publishers have started to implement it<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Watt | first1 = F. M. | last2 = Sever | first2 = R. | title = Non-profit publishing: Open access and the end of copyright transfer | doi = 10.1242/jcs.00873 | journal = Journal of Cell Science | volume = 117 | issue = Pt 1 | pages = 1 | year = 2004 | pmid = 14657267| pmc = }}</ref> using license agreements, wherein the author of the work retains copyright and gives the publisher the permission (exclusive or not) to reproduce and distribute the work. A third model is the so-called "browse-wrap" or "click-wrap" license model<ref>{{cite journal|last=Burk|first=Dan L.|title=Intellectual Property in the Context of e-Science |journal=Journal of Computer-Mediated Communication|year=2007|volume=12|issue=2|url=http://jcmc.indiana.edu/vol12/issue2/burk.html}}</ref> that is becoming more and more popular in the form of the [[Creative Commons]] licenses: it allows anyone (including the publisher) to reproduce and distribute the work, with some possible restrictions. Creative Commons licenses are used by many [[open access journal]]s.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Molloy | first1 = J. C. | title = The Open Knowledge Foundation: Open Data Means Better Science | journal = PLoS Biology | volume = 9 | issue = 12 | pages = e1001195 | year = 2011 | pmid = 22162946 | pmc = 3232214 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pbio.1001195}}</ref>
== Author addenda == Copyright transfer agreements are usually prepared by the publisher, and some print journals include a copy of the statement in every issue they published.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1007/BF00348410 | title = Forthcoming papers | journal = Applied Physics A: Solids and Surfaces | volume = 59 | pages = A5–A5 | year = 1994 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> If authors wish to deviate from the default phrasing – ''e.g.'', if they want to retain copyright or would not like to grant the publisher an exclusive right to publish – they can specify desired modifications, either by editing the document directly or by attaching an [[addendum#In contracts|addendum]] to a copy of the default version. Publisher policies on the acceptance of such addenda vary, though. Some institutions offer instructions and assistance for staff in creating such addenda.<ref>{{cite web|title=Author rights: using the SPARC Author Addendum to secure your rights as the author of a journal article|url=http://www.sparc.arl.org/resources/authors/addendum|work=SPARC|accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Amend a Publishing Agreement|url=https://osc.hul.harvard.edu/authors/amend|work=Harvard University Library|accessdate=20 November 2013}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works]] *[[Committee on Publication Ethics]] *[[ETBLAST]] *[[Fair use]] *[[Fraud]] *[[Intellectual property]] *[[Scientific misconduct]]
== References == {{reflist|colwidth=33em}}
== External links == *[http://www.pacificu.edu/libraries/services/scholarly-communication/author-rights/copyright-transfer-agreements Copyright Transfer Agreements] at [[Pacific University]] ([https://www.webcitation.org/6TKNlzOj8 WebCite copy]) *[http://oad.simmons.edu/oadwiki/Author_addenda Author addenda] at the [[Open Access Directory]]

revision.comment: consistent citation formatting; added missing PMIDs to cites
revision.text:
'''Creeping normality''' or '''[[Death by a thousand cuts (disambiguation)|death by a thousand cuts]]'''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Foster|first1=Mike | name-list-format = vanc |title=Soft commissions: Death by a thousand cuts|url=http://www.efinancialnews.com/story/2014-07-11/soft-commissions-for-asset-managers-face-a-thousand-cuts|publisher=[[Efinancialnews.com]]|access-date=2015-10-30|date=2014-07-11}}</ref> is the way a major change can be accepted as the normal situation if it happens slowly, in unnoticed increments. The change would be regarded as objectionable if it took place in a single step or short period.
The phrase was coined by American scientist, [[Jared Diamond]], in his 2005 book, [[Collapse: How Societies Choose to Fail or Succeed]]. He had previously alluded to this theory while attempting to explain why in the course of long-term [[environmental degradation]], [[Easter Island]] natives would, seemingly irrationally, chop down the last tree:<ref name=Diamond>{{cite web |last1=Diamond |first1=Jared |authorlink1=Jared Diamond |title=Easter's End |url= http://discovermagazine.com/1995/aug/eastersend543|publisher=Discover magazine |access-date=2014-08-03 |date=1995-08-01}}</ref>
{{Quote|"I suspect, though, that the disaster happened not with a bang but with a whimper. After all, there are those hundreds of abandoned statues to consider. The forest the islanders depended on for rollers and rope didn't simply disappear one day--it vanished slowly, over decades."|sign=|source=}}
In his book, Diamond also refers to creeping normality as landscape amnesia.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fogg|first=Graham E.|last2=LaBolle|first2=Eric M. | name-list-format = vanc |date=14 March 2006|title=Motivation of synthesis, with an example on groundwater quality sustainability |journal=Water Resources Research|volume=42|pages=W03S05|via=Google Scholar | doi = 10.1029/2005WR004372 }}</ref>
==Other uses== Creeping normality has been used to explain a number of different phenomenon, including the ones listed below:
=== Obese and overweight maternity patients === The term has also been used several times in conjunction with the increase of maternity patients who present as [[Obesity|obese]] and [[overweight]]. In their research article, authors Wilkinson, Poad, and Stapleton suggest that as the number of clinically obese or overweight pregnant women increase, the negative stigmatization with being so decreases.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Wilkinson SA, Poad D, Stapleton H | title = Maternal overweight and obesity: a survey of clinicians' characteristics and attitudes, and their responses to their pregnant clients | journal = BMC Pregnancy and Childbirth | volume = 13 | pages = 117 | date = May 2013 | pmid = 23692981 | doi = 10.1186/1471-2393-13-117 }}</ref> Schmeid, et al, states that as doctors see more women of an unhealthy weight, they are less likely to advise healthy weight gain goals during [[pregnancy]], out of fear of [[Social stigma of obesity|fat-shaming]].<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Schmied VA, Duff M, Dahlen HG, Mills AE, Kolt GS | title = 'Not waving but drowning': a study of the experiences and concerns of midwives and other health professionals caring for obese childbearing women | journal = Midwifery | volume = 27 | issue = 4 | pages = 424–30 | date = August 2011 | pmid = 20381222 | doi = 10.1016/j.midw.2010.02.010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Mills A, Schmied VA, Dahlen HG | title = 'Get alongside us', women's experiences of being overweight and pregnant in Sydney, Australia | journal = Maternal & Child Nutrition | volume = 9 | issue = 3 | pages = 309–21 | date = July 2013 | pmid = 22168548 | doi = 10.1111/j.1740-8709.2011.00386.x }}</ref> Because the shift in society to accept women of all body types has been so slow, physicians may not be aware that they are not addressing the [[Gestational age|gestational]] weight gain as soon as necessary.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Miller M, Hearn L, van der Pligt P, Wilcox J, Campbell KJ | title = Preventing maternal and early childhood obesity: the fetal flaw in Australian perinatal care | journal = Australian Journal of Primary Health | volume = 20 | issue = 2 | pages = 123–7 | date = 2014-06-06 | pmid = 24176286 | doi = 10.1071/PY13080 }}</ref> An anonymous survey was conducted from January to April, 2010, of obstetrics and gynecology residents. Of those surveyed, only "7.6 percent selected correct BMI ranges for each category, and only 5.8 percent selected correct gestational weight gain ranges".<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Moore Simas TA, Waring ME, Sullivan GM, Liao X, Rosal MC, Hardy JR, Berry RE | title = Institute of medicine 2009 gestational weight gain guideline knowledge: survey of obstetrics/gynecology and family medicine residents of the United States | journal = Birth | volume = 40 | issue = 4 | pages = 237–46 | date = December 2013 | pmid = 24344704 | pmc = 3974574 | doi = 10.1111/birt.12061 }}</ref>
=== Family Businesses === Antheaume and Barbelivien described the creeping normality that destroys businesses, causing them to not see the subtle, negative shifts in the community around them. The authors state that owners of [[Family business|family businesses]] are more likely to notice the small changes than a large [[corporation]], however "detecting a problem is no guarantee of the ability to solve it".<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://www.researchgate.net/publication/283300199_Why_do_family_businesses_die_An_investigation_through_the_work_of_an_ethnologist_and_geographer_on_the_collapse_of_human_societies |title=Why do family businesses die? An investigation through the work of an ethnologist and geographer on the collapse of human societies| vauthors = Antheaume N, Barbelivien D | website=Research Gate }}</ref>
=== Cybercrime === In his thesis, Chon states that the increase in [[cybercrime]] fits the pattern for creeping normality. The number of websites involved in "[[Security hacker|hacking]] and cybercrime activities"<ref>{{Cite journal| vauthors = Chon K | date=June 2016|title=Cybercrime precursors: Towards a model of offender resources|url=|journal=Australian National University|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> has increased at a slow and steady pace, mostly below society's awareness.
=== IPS-Nathan Lecture Series === Peter Ho referred to creeping normality in his four-part [[Institute of Policy Studies (Singapore)|IPS]]-Nathan lecture series in spring of 2017. In regards to several issues that [[Singapore]] is facing, he claimed that "things get just a little bit worse each year than the year before, but not bad enough for anyone to notice".<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Challenges of Governance in a Complex World|last=Tan|first=Ariel|last2=Ho|first2=Peter | name-list-format = vanc |publisher=World Scientific Publishing Company Pte Limited|year=2017|isbn=|location=|pages=11}}</ref> One example is through [[climate change]], where he stated that the country did not realize an increase of flooding was caused by rising temperatures, and not poor drainage as first suspected.
== See also == There are a number of metaphors related to creeping normality, including:{{div col|colwidth=32em}} * [[Boiling frog]] * [[Camel's nose]] * [[Gaslighting]] * [[Defeat in detail]] * "[[First they came ...]]" * [[Foot-in-the-door technique]] * [[Moving the goalposts]] * [[Overton window]] * ''[[Principiis obsta]]'' * [[Salami tactics]] * [[Shifting baseline]] * [[Slippery slope]] * [[Technological change#Technological change as a social process|Technological change as a social process]] * [[Tyranny of small decisions]] {{div col end}}
== References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Perception]] [[Category:Business terms]] [[Category:Technological change]] {{psychology-stub}} {{business-term-stub}}

revision.comment: corrected linking
revision.text:
{{Infobox dot-com company | name = CricHQ | logo = CricHQ.png | company_type = Private | foundation = {{Start date|2010}} | location = [[Wellington]], New Zealand | area_served = Worldwide | founder = | industry = [[Cricket]] | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | num_employees = | subsid = | url = {{URL|https://www.crichq.com/}} | programming_language = | ipv6 = | alexa = | website_type = | registration = | num_users = | language = | current_status = | screenshot = | caption = }}
'''CricHQ''' is a digital platform for sport which combines competition management and administration software with live scoring and statistics for [[cricket]] clubs.<ref name=Hutching>{{cite news|author=Hutching, Gerard|date=June 16, 2015|title=Singaporean firm invests US$10m in New Zealand cricket tech company|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/industries/69450909/singaporean-firm-invests-us10m-in-new-zealand-cricket-tech-company|work=Stuff|accessdate=July 4, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.trinidadexpress.com/20170125/sports/bassarath-don8217t-run-from-progress|title=Bassarath: Don’t run from progress|last=|first=|date=|website=Trinidad Express|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=12 May 2017}}</ref> It is based in [[Wellington]], New Zealand, and was set up by CEO Simon Baker and former New Zealand cricketers [[Stephen Fleming]] and [[Brendon McCullum]]. It manages the administration of cricket test countries New Zealand, Sri Lanka, South Africa and Zimbabwe. A number of other national governing bodies also use its services from club level upwards (see National Governing Bodies section below).<ref name=Harris>{{cite news|author=Harris, Catherine|date=October 30, 2015|title=NZ's CricHQ scores digital deals with Zimbabwe and South Africa|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/73511988/NZs-CricHQ-scores-digital-deals-with-Zimbabwe-and-South-Africa|work=Stuff|accessdate=July 4, 2016}}</ref>
The company provides a range of digital services to cricket organisations that typically use paper-based administration and scoring. The services include instant updates for fans, performance insights for coaches and the ability to set up cricket-related social networks. It also makes it easier to register players, organise competition draws and analyse demographics of sport participants.
When the app was launched it was briefly one of the world's most downloaded sporting apps <ref name=Rutherford>{{cite news|author=Hamish, Rutherford|date=September 11, 2016|title=From unstable start-up, CricHQ bids for global domination of cricket scoring|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/83774547/from-unstable-startup-crichq-bids-for-global-domination-of-cricket-scoring|work=Fairfax|accessdate=September 12, 2016}}</ref> and since then it has amassed over 1 million Facebook fans.<ref name=LIN>{{cite news|author=Tao, Lin|date=August 22, 2016|title=New academy launches to educate SMEs on social media|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/small-business/83294086/New-academy-launches-to-educate-SMEs-on-social-media|work=Fairfax|accessdate=September 19, 2016}}</ref>
The company has been described as "one of New Zealand’s largely unsung tech success stories" by one of New Zealand's leading technology journalists.<ref name=KeallC>{{cite news|author=Keall, Chris|date=September 2, 2016|title=Stephen Fleming and Brendon McCullum as software billionaires?|url=http://www.nbr.co.nz/crichq-ck|work=NBR|accessdate=September 4, 2016}}</ref>
In October 2016, CricHQ's then-Executive Chair, Mike Loftus, was invited to visit [[India]] with New Zealand's Prime Minister, [[John Key]], as part of a trade delegation.<ref name=NicholasJones>{{cite news|author=Jones, Nicholas|date=October 17, 2016|title=McCullum jets off with Key to open doors for cricket firm expansion in India|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=11734371|work=NZHerald|accessdate=November 1, 2016}}</ref>
In December 2016, former [[Saatchi & Saatchi]] Chair and CEO [[Kevin Roberts (businessman)]] was appointed as Chair of CricHQ's board.<ref name="HamishMcNicol">{{cite news|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/business/97988030/wellington-technology-company-crichq-placed-in-receivership-after-failing-to-attract-new-investment|title=Wellington technology company CricHQ placed in receivership|last=|first=|date=October 17, 2017|work=Fairfax|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
In October 2017, CricHQ was put in voluntary receivership by majority shareholders [[Tembusu Partners Private Limited|Tembusu Partners]] who appointed insolvency experts KordaMentha to sell the business. CricHQ was purchased by a group of private investors and continues to trade. [https://www.stuff.co.nz/business/97988030/wellington-technology-company-crichq-placed-in-receivership-after-failing-to-attract-new-investment]
== Video content == In 2017, CricHQ acquired My Action Replay, a sportstech company based in [[Bristol]]. My Action Replay provides cameras and the capability for sports teams to [[Streaming media|livestream]] their games and to package up highlights to be hosted online. With CricHQ's customer base, the acquisition of My Action Replay could make CricHQ the largest broadcaster of cricket in the world.<ref name=HMcNicol>{{cite news|author=McNicol, Hamish|date=March 2, 2017|title=CricHQ wants to become world's largest cricket broadcaster after buying video business|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/cricket/89937880/crichq-wants-to-become-worlds-largest-cricket-broadcaster-after-buying-video-business|work=Fairfax|accessdate=March 20, 2017}}</ref>
== Investment == In June 2015 CricHQ raised US$10m from Singapore private equity firm [[Tembusu Partners Private Limited|Tembusu Partners]] to expand globally including a doubling of staff in India, the world's largest cricketing nation.<ref name=GerardHutching>{{cite news|author=Hutching, Gerard|date=June 16, 2015|title=Singaporean firm invests US$10m in New Zealand cricket tech company|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/industries/69450909/singaporean-firm-invests-us10m-in-new-zealand-cricket-tech-company|work=Fairfax|accessdate=November 1, 2016}}</ref>
In September 2016 it was revealed that CricHQ was seeking further investment of US$10M and was in discussions with [[Investment Banking|investment bankers]] in the [[United States]] and [[United Kingdom]]. It also stated that the company was valued at US$70M while forecast to make a loss of more than US$4m in the 2016/17 financial year.<ref name=Rutherford2>{{cite news|author=Rutherford, Hamish|date=September 20, 2016|title=Wellington's CricHQ seeks US$10 million from investors for expansion|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/84465086/wellingtons-crichq-seeks-us10-million-from-investors-for-expansion|work=Fairfax|accessdate=September 21, 2016}}</ref>
Incoming Chair [[Kevin Roberts (businessman)]] revealed that he had invested a "seven figure" sum in the company in December 2016.<ref name=HamishMcNicol/>
== National Governing Bodies ==
As well as having a partnership with the [[International Cricket Council]], CricHQ signed Hong Kong as its 50th cricketing National Governing Body in August 2016.<ref name=BusinessStandard>{{cite news|author=Trust, Press|date=September 4, 2016|title=CricHQ enters into partnership with Hong Kong CA|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/crichq-enters-into-partnership-with-hong-kong-ca-116090400445_1.html|work=Business Standard|accessdate=September 5, 2016}}</ref> As of May 2017, 54 National Governing Bodies have been signed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nzbusiness.co.nz/article/stroke-genius|title=A stroke of genius|last=|first=|date=|website=NZBusiness|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=12 May 2017}}</ref> The full list of National Governing Bodies that CricHQ has signed with is:<ref name="KeallC"/>
* [[New Zealand Cricket|New Zealand]] * [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]] * [[Sri Lanka Cricket|Sri Lanka]] * [[Zimbabwe Cricket|Zimbabwe]] * [[Afghanistan Cricket Board|Afghanistan]] * [[Belgian Cricket Federation|Belgium]] * [[Botswana Cricket Association|Botswana]] * [[Canada cricket team|Canada]] * [[France cricket team|France]] * [[German Cricket Federation|Germany]] * [[Gibraltar Cricket Association|Gibraltar]] * [[Guernsey Cricket Board|Guernsey]] * [[Ireland Cricket team|Ireland]] * [[Japan Cricket Association|Japan]] * [[Jersey Cricket Board|Jersey]] * [[Namibia Cricket Board|Namibia]] * [[Nepal cricket team|Nepal]] * [[Papua New Guinea Cricket Board|Papua New Guinea]] * [[Scottish cricket|Scotland]] * [[Singapore Cricket Association|Singapore]] * [[United Arab Emirates Cricket Board|UAE]] * [[United States Cricket Association|USA]] * [[Vanuatu Cricket Association|Vanuatu]] * [[Zambia Cricket Union|Zambia]] * [[Austrian Cricket Association|Austria]] * [[Chilean Cricket Association|Chile]] * [[Cook Islands Cricket Association|Cook Islands]] * [[Cyprus Cricket Association|Cyprus]] * [[Estonia Cricket Association|Estonia]] * [[Finland cricket team|Finland]] * [[Hungarian Cricket Association|Hungary]] * [[Indonesian cricket team|Indonesia]] * [[Malawi Cricket Association|Malawi]] * [[Maldives cricket team|Maldives]] * [[Malta Cricket Association|Malta]] * [[Mexico Cricket Association|Mexico]] * [[Norway cricket team|Norway]] * [[Oman Cricket|Oman]] * [[Philippines Cricket Association|Philippines]] * [[Portuguese Cricket Federation|Portugal]] * [[Russian cricket team|Russia]] * [[Sierra Leone Cricket Association|Sierra Leone]] * [[Taiwan]] * [[Vietnam]] * [[Czech cricket team|Czech Republic]] * [[Nigeria Cricket Federation|Nigeria]] * [[Brazil cricket team|Brazil]] * [[Qatar Cricket Association|Qatar]] * [[Rwanda Cricket Association|Rwanda]] * [[Hong Kong Cricket Association|Hong Kong]] * [[Trinidad and Tobago national cricket team|Trinidad & Tobago]]
== Awards ==
* In May 2017, CricHQ won the Best-Integrated Digital Media award at the [[Sports Technology Awards]], a global award recognising the best in Sports Tech in the world <ref name="NZHeraldCook">{{cite news|last1=Cook|first1=Francis|title=New Zealand cricket app wins major award|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=11851631|accessdate=9 May 2017|agency=NZME|publisher=NZHerald|date=8 May 2017}}</ref> * In March 2017, CricHQ was shortlisted as a finalist in the UK [[Sports Technology Awards]] in the Best-Integrated Digital Media category.<ref name="sports technology awards">{{cite web|url=http://www.sportstechnologyawards.com/the-shortlist/|publisher=sportstechnologyawards.com|title=Sports Technology Awards - shortlist|accessdate=March 3, 2017}}</ref> * In September 2016, CricHQ was announced as a finalist in the New Zealand Innovation Awards in the Innovation in technology solutions section and as the Emerging New Zealand innovator.<ref name="innovators">{{cite web|url=http://www.innovators.org.nz/winners-a-finalists/finalists-2016|publisher=innovators.org.nz|title=NZIA - Finalists 2016|accessdate=September 27, 2016}}</ref> CricHQ was highly commended in the Emerging Innovator award <ref name="Innovators2">{{cite web|url=http://www.innovationawards.org.nz/winners-a-finalists/winners-2016|publisher=innovators.org.nz|title=NZIA - Winners 2016|accessdate=November 1, 2016}}</ref> * In July 2016, CricHQ won the Excellence in Software Award at the New Zealand Excellence in IT Awards.<ref name="nbr">{{cite web|url=http://www.nbr.co.nz/article/raw-data-excellence-it-awards-handed-out-gala-event-b-191522|publisher=nbr.co.nz|title=RAW DATA: Excellence in IT Awards handed out at gala event | The National Business Review|accessdate=September 27, 2016}}</ref> * CricHQ was awarded a National Award for Excellence in Digital Marketing & Social Media at the 2016 CMO Asia Awards for [http://www.socialsamosa.com/2016/07/case-study-icareisupport-drought-stricken-farmers/ its #ICareISupport campaign] to help raise money for drought-stricken farmers in Maharashtra.<ref name="cmoasia">{{cite web|url=http://www.cmoasia.org/SocialMedia&DigitalMarketing_awards2016.html|publisher=cmoasia.org|title=CMO ASIA|accessdate=September 27, 2016}}</ref>

/* Tsunami recovery systems<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pacificdisaster.net/pdnadmin/data/original/ADB_2006_PN40157_REG_TAR.pdf|title=Support for Strengthening the Tsunami Development Assistance Database|date=2006-06-01|w using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The '''Development Assistance Database''' (DAD) is an Aid Information Management System (AIMS) developed by [[Synergy International Systems]],<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://isiafrica.net/directory/aid/|title = Aid – isiAfrica|website = isiafrica.net|access-date = 2016-03-04}}</ref> for tracking [[development aid]] and managing [[official development assistance]] with transparency and accountability.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.undp.org/content/dam/aplaws/publication/en/publications/capacity-development/aid-information-management-systems-in-post-conflict-and-fragile-situations/UNDP_AIMS_in_Post-Conflict_and_Fragile_Situations.pdf|title = Comparative Experience: Aid Information Management Systems in Post-Conflict and Fragile Situations|date = 2010-10-01|website =|publisher = United Nations Development Programme|access-date =}}</ref> DAD is widely adopted AIMS<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.publishwhatyoufund.org/files/Practical-Approaches-to-the-Aid-Effectiveness-Agenda.pdf|title=Practical approaches to the aid effectiveness agenda "Evidence in aligning aid information with recipient country budgets"|last=Samuel Moon with Zachary Mills|date=2010-07-01|website=|publisher=Overseas Development Institute and Publish What You Fund|access-date=}}</ref> which has been established in more than 35 countries<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/dac/aft/48395729.pdf|title=How have aid for trade flows evolved?|date=|website=|publisher=OECD, WTO|access-date=}}</ref> worldwide in close cooperation with [[United Nations Development Programme|UNDP]] and respective governments.
DAD provides country governments<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.undp.org/content/dam/yemen/DemDov/Docs/UNDP-YEM-DAD_FINAL.pdf|title=Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation DAD YEMEN FACT SHEET|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> and development partners with a consolidated source of data on development projects across all donors, demonstrates "who is doing what, when and where" in managing foreign aid,<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalplanning.gov.ng/index.php/initiatives/dad-nigeria|title=Federal Ministry of Budget and National Planning of Nigeria, DAD Nigeria|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> enables harmonization of development projects with national priorities, facilitates management and coordination of development efforts in the country<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tulaneict4d.wordpress.com/2011/11/07/development-assistance-database-dad/|title=Development Assistance Database (DAD)|date=2011-11-01|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> by and promotes results-driven decision-making and [[aid effectiveness]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/useofiatidataincountrysystems/the-guide/aims|title=AIMS and public financial management|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
DAD serves /has served as the official government AIMS in Afghanistan,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/countries/afghanistan/47543433.pdf|title=JOINT EVALUATION OF THE PARIS DECLARATION PHASE 2:ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF AFGHANISTAN|author1=ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF AFGHANISTAN |author2=BAWAAR Consulting Group |date=2010-01-01|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Armenia, Burundi, Cameroon, Central African Republic,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/dacfragilestates/47278388.pdf|title=FRAGILE STATES PRINCIPLES.Good Practice Cases|last=United Nations Development Programme|date=2011-02-24|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Comoros, Georgia, Ghana, Guatemala, India, Indonesia, Iraq (including Kurdistan Regional Government),<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://csis.org/files/media/csis/pubs/070813-barton-strengthcapiraq.pdf|title=Strengthening Capacity Building and Public-sector Management in Iraq: A Report of the Post-Conflict Reconstruction Project Center for Strategic and International Studies|last=Andrew Rathmell|first=Paul S. Frederiksen,Shannon Hayden, Sasha Kishinchand|date=2007-08-01|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Kazakhstan, Kenya, Maldives, Mauritania, Nigeria,<ref name=":2" /> Lesotho,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ls.undp.org/content/dam/lesotho/docs/Other/RCAR_2013_LES_NAR.pdf|title=2013 Resident Coordinator Annual Report, Lesotho|last=United Nations Development Programme|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Pakistan,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/Pakistan%203.pdf|title=Pakistan|date=2012-09-09|website=|publisher=Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|access-date=}}</ref> Papua New Guinea,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/42298773.pdf|title=PAPUA NEW GUINEA|date=|website=|publisher=Organisation for economic co-operation and development|access-date=}}</ref> Philippines, Russia, Rwanda,<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/dac/aft/RwandaCaseStudyFinal.pdf|title=MANAGING AID FOR TRADE AND DEVELOPMENT RESULTS: Rwanda Case Study|author1=Richard Newfarmer |author2=Michele Savini |author3=Zangrandi Mariana Vijil |date=2013-01-12|website=|publisher=OECD, IGC|access-date=}}</ref> Sierra Leone,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.humanitarianresponse.info/sites/www.humanitarianresponse.info/files/assessments/undp_2009_daco_final_evaluation_and_sl_aid_architecture_review_-_final_report_0.pdf|title=End-of-Project Evaluation of‘Support to Development Assistance Coordination Office’& Review of Sierra Leone’s Aid Coordination Architecture|author1=Stuart Black |author2=Jörg Nadoll |author3=Yaw Adu-Boahene |date=2009-09-01|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Sri Lanka,<ref name="Business Wire">{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20060622005665/en/Sri-Lanka-Deploys-Housing-Tracking-Module-Synergy|title=Sri Lanka Deploys Housing Tracking Module in Synergy Development Assistance Database and Portal; eGovernment Solution Gives Transparent View of Asian Tsunami Recovery Progress|date=2006-06-22|website=|publisher=Business Wire|access-date=}}</ref> Somalia (including Somaliland),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.so.undp.org/content/somalia/en/home/ourwork/democraticgovernance/successstories/aid-effectiveness-dad.html|title=Improving Aid Effectiveness in Somalia|date=|website=|publisher=United Nations Development Programme|access-date=}}</ref> Solomon Islands,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fj.undp.org/content/fiji/en/home/operations/projects/poverty_reduction/SOI_aid.html|title=Solomon Islands Aid Coordination and Management|date=|website=|publisher=United Nations Development Fund|access-date=}}</ref> Tajikistan, Thailand, Ukraine,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ua.undp.org/content/ukraine/en/home/operations/projects/democratic_governance/project_sample112111.html|title=Support to better coordination and management of international aid/assistance (through establishment of the development assistance database - DAD)|date=|website=|publisher=United Nations Development Programme|access-date=}}</ref> Vietnam,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/derec/denmark/42225059.pdf|title=Provision of Technical Assistance Personnel in Vietnam|author1=David Watson |author2=Nguyen Minh Thong |author3=Julia Zinke |date=2007-09-01|website=|publisher=European Centre for Development Policy Management|access-date=}}</ref> Yemen<ref name=":1" /> and Zambia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/countries/zambia/46750073.pdf|title=Evaluation of the Joint Assistance Strategy for Zambia (JASZ) 2007-10|date=2010-06-01|website=|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark|access-date=}}</ref>
==History==
Originally known as the Donor Assistance Database, the DAD was re-branded as the Development Assistance Database on August 2, 2005. The first Donor Assistance Database was a [[Personal Computer|PC]] system developed in the scope of the G7 Support Implementation Group project for <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/pnabz352.pdf|title=Business Toolkit for Russian Enterprises "Professional Associations Component"|date=1996-09-01|website=|publisher=Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu JLA Group Ltd.|access-date=}}</ref>[[Russia]] in 1996 to monitor aid assistance donated from the international community. The first Donor Assistance Database tracked 20,000 projects and over US $100 billion in Official Development Assistance delivered between 1991 and 2001.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.friends-partners.org/partners/ccsi/print/region/directry.htm|title=Directory of U.S. Technical Assistance Activities in Russia|date=1996-09-01|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> The DAD was then adapted as a tool for the Newly Independent States of the former Soviet Union to monitor development assistance from the international community. These first generation implementations include [[Armenia]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Turkmenistan]], [[Ukraine]], and [[Tajikistan]].
Most of these implementations have taken place through a partnership between the software company Synergy International Systems, and the [[United Nations Development Programme]] (UNDP). This partnership led to the signing of a Long Term Agreement in July, 2005.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sz.undp.org/content/dam/swaziland/docs/publications/UNDP_SZ_Poverty_DonorDatabaseStudy2012.pdf|title=Study to Establish a Donor database in the Kingdom of Swaziland|date=2012-09-01|website=|publisher=Government of Swaziland With Support from UNDP|access-date=}}</ref>
==Functions and Capabilities<ref name=":0" /> == '''Online, offline and mobile collection of aid information''' – DAD’s customized data entry forms with validation control enable to submit and update aid information though web-based interface, in offline mode which is specifically for use in areas with limited or no Internet access as well as through smartphones and tablets.
'''Sector Profile''' – This functionality displays aggregate data related to particular sectors, including aid flows and projects in a given sector, donors involved, and results achieved. The Sector Profile can have all relevant information on sector portfolio performance, logistics etc.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20040413005218/en/Synergy-International-Systems-Provide-Donor-Assistance-Management|title=Synergy International Systems to Provide Donor Assistance Management for Iraqi Reconstruction Efforts|date=2004-04-13|website=|publisher=Business Wire|access-date=}}</ref>
'''Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E''''')'' – DAD enables to link aid projects with the government's policy priorities and national development strategies, and monitor progress in respect to targets/goals to track progress toward development results.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalplanning.gov.ng/images/docs/DADNigeria/DAD%202nd%20Quarter%20report%202014.pdf|title=Development Assistance Database (DAD Nigeria) 2nd Quarter REPORT 2014|last=Henry Asor|date=2014-07-03|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
'''Data visualization and analytics''' – DAD offers a suite of web-based querying, analytics, visualization, and reporting tools - graphs, charts, tables, reports– for visualizing and interpreting aid information.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://info.undp.org/docs/pdc/Documents/UKR/Project%20Document_Support%20to%20better%20coordination%20and%20management%20of%20international%20aid%20assistance%20%20_DAD.pdf|title=Support to better coordination and management of international aid/assistance ( through establishment of the development assistance database DAD)|date=2012-03-29|website=|publisher=United Nations Development Programme|access-date=}}</ref>
'''Executive dashboard''' – This decision-support tool displays data snapshots of aid flows (pledges, commitments, disbursements, and expenditures) and enables simultaneous viewing of all analytical outputs.
'''Geographic Information System -''' DAD platform contains a Geographic Information System (GIS) mapping feature that allows to view geo-referenced data on project activities and results at various geographic levels and also to query or filter data on the web-based dynamic maps.
'''Aid Effectiveness Portal''' – DAD provides a range of knowledge sharing and collaboration tools to make aid information available to the public.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/presscenter/pressreleases/2010/04/22/new-online-portal-to-promote-efficient-use-of-aid-in-haitian-earthquake-recovery.html|title=New online portal to promote efficient use of aid in Haiti|date=2010-04-22|website=|publisher=United Nations Development Programme|access-date=}}</ref>
'''Integration''' – DAD can interface with relevant external and internal data sources in order to automate data exchange to enable effective flow of information and prevent duplication of effort and silos of information.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aidtransparency.net/reports/IATI-annual-report-2014.pdf|title=Annual Report 2014|date=|website=|publisher=International Aid Transparency Initiative (IATI)|access-date=}}</ref>
'''Multi-lingual capability''' – DAD can be adapted to the specific needs of a given country, including the localization of the software into the national language.<ref name=":4" />
== DAD Featured Projects ==
===Rwanda<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/countries/rwanda/45582738.pdf|title=State building in fragile situations –How can donors ‘do no harm’ and maximize their positive impact? : Country case study – Rwanda|date=2009-07-01|website=|publisher=London School of Economics and PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP|access-date=}}</ref>=== DAD Rwanda is Rwanda’s official development aid (ODA) coordination system. It is used by the Ministry of Finance and Economy (MINECOFIN) to track and manage aid funds and development results across all major donors and NGOs.<ref name=":3" /> The system captures the national Donor Performance Assessment Framework (DPAF) mutual accountability framework, indicators and standard definitions and is used for annual Rwanda ODA Effectiveness reports. In 2010 an upgrade of the DAD resulted in establishing a new MTEF module with the view of systematically capturing forward-spending plans of Development Partners to feed into the MTEF process.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/derec/unitedkingdom/11_EvaluationSupportPublicFinanceManagement%20ReformRwanda.pdf|title=Rwanda: Independent Evaluation of the Implementation of the PFM Reform Strategy 2008-2012|date=2012-11-01|website=|publisher=ECORYS Nederland BV|access-date=}}</ref> DAD Rwanda was also integrated with Rwanda’s SmartFMIS budgeting platform that resulted in more external funds flowing directly to Ministry of Planning for spending.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aidtransparency.net/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/IATI-Country-Pilots.pdf|title=IATI Delivering at National Level|last=Ronald Nkusi, MINECOFIN, Rwanda|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Transparent governance has improved Rwanda’s Business Environment rankings and Rwanda’s data-driven model for aid management has been emulated by Burundi, Cameroon, Mauritania and Central African Republic.
=== Iraq === Launched in 2011 Iraq Development Management System (IDMS) is a web-based planning, budgeting and results tracking system used by the Iraq Ministry of Planning (MoP) to manage the entire cycle of government and donor-funded projects.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gcn.com/articles/2004/05/03/database-will-help-track-international-aid-in-iraq.aspx|title=Database will help track international aid in Iraq|last=Dawn S. Onley|date=2004-06-03|website=gcn.com|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> IDMS covers 3000 projects with a total value of US$186 billion under the National Development Plan (NDP) 2010-2014. The system automates submission of new project proposals, annual and monthly budget preparation, advanced performance tracking, analysis, and reporting features. It uses both English and Arabic, and provides public access to data on key accountability metrics. IDMS was developed in partnership with UNDP, USAID-Tatweer, the EU and UNOPS.<ref name=":5" />
=== Tsunami recovery systems<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pacificdisaster.net/pdnadmin/data/original/ADB_2006_PN40157_REG_TAR.pdf|title=Support for Strengthening the Tsunami Development Assistance Database|date=2006-06-01|website=|publisher=Asian Development Bank|access-date=}}</ref> === Following the devastating [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami|2004 Asian tsunami]] with the support of UNDP, Development Assistance Database was established in tsunami affected countries - Sri Lanka, Maldives and Thailand and Indonesia, to track financial and technical assistance, as well as results related to tsunami recovery work.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/site/adboecdanti-corruptioninitiative/partnerships/36771059.pdf|title=Knowledge commitment action against corruption in Asia and the Pacific|date=2006-01-01|website=|publisher=Asian Development Bank, Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|access-date=}}</ref>
'''DAD Sri Lanka''' – The Integrated National Development Information System (INDIS) was first introduced in Sri Lanka in 2005 following the devastating 2004 Asian tsunami to help the Government of Sri Lanka to track disaster needs, plan recovery programs and promote visibility and accountability in project spending and performance.<ref name="Business Wire"/> INDIS allowed reconstruction agencies to report their projects and share information on objectives, funding sources, implementation partners and project progress online, with the ultimate goal of facilitating efficient aid coordination.
'''DAD Indonesia''' - Synergy built the Recovery Aceh Nias (RAN) Database for the Government of Indonesia to support its coordination and management of the post-tsunami recovery effort. The RAN assisted the Government to align proposed projects with national reconstruction priorities, ensuring a coordinated plan for the delivery of aid. The RAN Database was the central tool for coordinating tsunami recovery activities and to date has tracked $3.7 billion in disbursements. Synergy was awarded the Innovative Government Technology Award in the Information Management category at the 2008 FutureGov Summit for the development of the Recovery Aceh Nias (RAN) Database installed for the BRR – Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Agency of the Government of Indonesia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pacificdisaster.net/pdnadmin/data/original/ADB_2009_PN40157_09REG_TACR.pdf|title=Regional: Support for Strengthening the Tsunami Development Assistance Database|last=Aidan Cox|date=2009-04-01|website=|publisher=Asian Development Bank|access-date=}}</ref>
'''DAD Maldives''' - Synergy was contracted by the government of Maldives to implemented the Development Assistance Database (DAD) that was later linked with the National Recovery Reconstruction Plan (NRRP). This helped to implement a key tenet of the Paris Declaration by “aligning” projects with national priorities as outlined in the NRRP and add the accountability mechanism.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/countries/maldives/47865168.pdf|title=ASSESSMENT OF DEVELOPMENT RESULTS,EVALUATION OF UNDP CONTRIBUTI ON MALDIVES|date=2010-03-01|website=|publisher=United Nations Development Programme|access-date=}}</ref>
'''DAD Thailand''' - Synergy customized the DAD for the Thailand International Cooperation Agency located within the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Launched in 2005, DAD Thailand, has significantly improved coordination and monitoring of the long-term international support to tsunami recovery in Thailand.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/site/adboecdanti-corruptioninitiative/regionalseminars/35593179.pdf|title=Corruption, development and human rights – Fighting corruption as a means to achieve the Millennium Development Goals|last=Patrick Keuleers|date=|website=|publisher=UNDP Regional Centre for Asia and the Pacific – Bangkok|access-date=}}</ref>
== DAD Community of Practice == The Development Assistance Database (DAD) Community of Practice (CoP) is a global forum of practitioners who share a common commitment to advancing development effectiveness through the application of DAD.
<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.africa-platform.org/sites/default/files/resources/DAD%20CoP%202011%20Synthesis%20Report.pdf|title=Taking Stock of the DAD Community of Practice 2009-2011|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> The major event of the DAD CoP is a biennial conference that brings together participants representing governments, aid agencies, civil society organizations, think-tanks, and the private sector. The conference centers on a workshop that features case studies in implementing DAD to improve management of development data.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/46080636.pdf|title=South Africa—Development in the Southern African region|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
The DAD CoP currently has over 80 members from about 20 countries, including Afghanistan, Armenia, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Comoros, India, Iraq, Kenya, Lesotho, Mauritania, Moldova, Mozambique, Namibia, Pakistan, Sierra Leone, Solomon Islands, Somalia, Sri Lanka, Tajikistan, and Yemen. The International Aid Transparency Initiative (IATI) also participates in the DAD CoP.
Three DAD CoP forums have been organized so far - DAD CoP 2014, Nairobi, Kenya,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalplanning.gov.ng/images/docs/DADNigeria/DAD%20CoP%20report%202014.pdf|title=REPORT ON 3RD DAD CoP CONFERENCE HELD IN NAIROBI, KENYA|last=Henry Asor|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> DAD CoP 2011, Yerevan, Armenia and DAD CoP 2009 Yerevan, Armenia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.southsouthcases.info/casosasia/caso_16.php|title=DAD – South-South learning on aid information and development effectiveness|date=|website=|publisher=South South cases|access-date=}}</ref>
== See also == [[Synergy International Systems]]
==External links== *[http://www.synisys.com Synergy International Systems, Inc.]
==References== <references/>

revision.comment: Fixed spelling of "discriminated"

/* Overview */ Corrected factual errors about the origin of "dynamic capabilities" (Nonaka and Takeuchi did not attribute it to Prahalad and Hamel) and cleaned up related text (It was redundant to call out Shuen as an originator since the new text lists her as one of the authors of the initial article..
revision.text:
In [[organizational theory]], '''dynamic capability''' is the capability of an organization to purposefully adapt an organization's resource base. The concept was defined by [[David Teece]], Gary Pisano and Amy Shuen, in their 1997 paper ''Dynamic Capabilities and Strategic Management'', as "the firm’s ability to integrate, build, and reconfigure internal and external competences to address rapidly changing environments".<ref name="Teece et al.">{{cite journal|last2 = Pisano|first2 = Gary|last3 = Shuen|first3 = Amy|date = August 1997|title = Dynamic Capabilities and Strategic Management|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/(SICI)1097-0266(199708)18:7%3C509::AID-SMJ882%3E3.0.CO;2-Z/epdf|journal = [[Strategic Management Journal]]|volume = 18|issue = 7|pages = 509–533|last1 = Teece|first1 = David|doi=10.1002/(sici)1097-0266(199708)18:7<509::aid-smj882>3.0.co;2-z}}</ref>
The term is often used in the plural form, '''dynamic capabilities''', emphasizing that the ability to react adequately and timely to external changes requires a combination of multiple capabilities.
== Overview == The phrase "dynamic capabilities" was introduced in a working paper by [[David Teece]], [[Gary Pisano]], and Amy Shuen.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Teece |first1=David |last2=Pisano |first2=Gary |last3=Shuen |first3=Amy |title=Firm Capabilities, Resources, and the Concept of Strategy |date=1990 |publisher=Center for Research on Management |location=University of California, Berkeley |edition=CCC Working Paper 90–8}}</ref>The final, peer-reviewed version was published in 1997.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Teece |first1=David J. |last2=Pisano |first2=Gary |last3=Shuen |first3=Amy |title=Dynamic capabilities and strategic management |journal=Strategic Management Journal |date=August 1997 |volume=18 |issue=7 |pages=509–533 |doi=10.1002/(SICI)1097-0266(199708)18:7%3C509::AID-SMJ882%3E3.0.CO;2-Z}}</ref>
The idea of dynamic capabilities is similar in some ways to the previously existing concept of operational capabilities; the latter pertains to the current operations of an organization, whereas the former, by contrast, refers to an organization's capacity to efficiently and responsively change these operations and develop its resources.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Helfat|first1=Constance E. |last2=Finkelstein |first2=Sydney |last3=Mitchell |first3=Will |last4=Peteraf |first4=Margaret |last5=Singh |first5=Harbir |last6=Teece |first6=David |last7=Winter |first7=Sidney G. |title=Dynamic Capabilities: Understanding Strategic Change in Organizations |year=2009 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |isbn=9781405182065 |url= https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=u0Tuh5vixLkC&oi=fnd&pg=PR6&dq=%22Dynamic+Capabilities:+Understanding+strategic+change+in+organizations |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref>
The main assumption of this framework is that an organization's basic competencies should be used to create short-term competitive positions that can be developed into longer-term competitive advantage. Nelson and Winter, in their 1982 book ''An Evolutionary Theory of Economic Change'', link the growth of the concept of dynamic capabilities to the [[resource-based view]] of the firm and the concept of "routines" in evolutionary theories of organization.<ref name="Nelson1982">{{cite book|first=Richard R. |last=Nelson |title=An Evolutionary Theory of Economic Change |year=1982 |publisher=Belknap Press of Harvard University Press |isbn=978-0-674-27228-6}}</ref> Douma and Scheuder describe it as a bridge between the economics-based strategy literature and evolutionary approaches to organizations.<ref name="DoumaSchreuder2002">{{cite book|last1=Douma |first1=Sytse |authorlink1=Sytse Douma |last2=Schreuder |first2=Hein |authorlink2=Hein Schreuder |title=Economic Approaches to Organizations |edition=Third |year=2002 |publisher=Financial Times Prentice Hall |isbn=9780273651994}}</ref>
The resource-based view of the firm emphasizes sustainable competitive advantage; the dynamic capabilities view, on the other hand, focuses more on the issue of competitive survival in response to rapidly changing contemporary business conditions. Strategy scholars Gregory Ludwig and Jon Pemberton, in one of the few empirical studies on the topic, called for clarification of the specific processes of dynamic capability building in particular industries to make the concept more useful to senior managers who set directions for their firms.<ref name="Ludwig 2011 pp.215-236">{{cite journal|last1=Ludwig|first1=Gregory |last2=Pemberton |first2=Jon |title=A managerial perspective of dynamic capabilities in emerging markets: The case of the Russian steel industry |journal=Journal for East European Management Studies |issn=0949-6181 |year=2011 |volume=16 |issue=3 |pages=215–236 |jstor= 23281688}}</ref>
Dynamic capabilities theory concerns the development of strategies for senior managers of successful companies to adapt to radical discontinuous change, while maintaining minimum capability standards to ensure competitive survival. For example, industries which have traditionally relied on a specific manufacturing process can't always change this process on short notice when a new technology arrives; when this happens, managers need to adapt their own routines to make the most of their existing resources while simultaneously planning for future process changes as the resources depreciate.<ref name="Ludwig 2011 pp.215-236"/>
The New Dynamic Capabilities framework, posed by Amy Shuen in her analysis of Web 2.0, focuses on the firm's ability to quickly orchestrate and reconfigure externally sourced competences,ranging from Apple, Google Android, IBM Linux developer ecosystems to crowdsourced, crowdfunded open innovations such as the Obama08 mobile app—while leveraging internal resources such as platforms, know-how, user communities and digital, social and mobile networks.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Shuen |first1=Amy |last2=Sieber |first2=Sandra |title=Orchestrating the New Dynamic Capabilities |journal=IESE Insight Review|date=2009 |issue=3 |pages=58–65 |url= http://www.ieseinsight.com/review/articulo.aspx?doc=5445&seccion=6 |accessdate=7 December 2017 |doi=10.15581/002.art-1605}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Shuen |first=Amy |title=Web 2.0: A Strategy Guide: Business thinking and strategies behind successful Web 2.0 implementations |year=2008 |publisher=O'Reilly Media |isbn=9780596553753}}</ref> The New Dynamic Capabilities framework takes into account digital, information and network economics<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shapiro |first1=Carl |last2=Varian |first2=Hal R. |title=Information Rules: A Strategic Guide to the Network Economy |year=1998 |publisher=Harvard Business Review Press |isbn=9780875848631}}</ref> and the fall of the transaction costs of involved in using specialized services.<ref>{{cite web|last=Williamson |first=Oliver E. |title=Nobel Prize Lecture: Transaction Cost Economics: The Natural Progression |url= https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/economic-sciences/laureates/2009/williamson-lecture.html |website=nobelprize.org |date=8 December 2009 |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref> According to Philip Cordes-Berszinn, though, more research is needed in order to measure the "capabilities" and to appropriately apply the ideas to practical management situations.<ref name=berszinn>{{cite book|last1=Cordes-Berszinn|first1=Philip|title=Dynamic Capabilities: How Organisational Structures Affect Knowledge Processes|date=November 2013|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|url=http://www.palgrave.com/page/detail/dynamic-capabilities-philip-cordesberszinn/?K=9781137351272|accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref>
== Processes == A detailed description of processes and theoretical roots is provided by Arndt, Pierce, and Teece (2017). Teece, Pisano, and Shuen proposed three dynamic capabilities as necessary for an organization to meet new challenges: the ability of employees to learn quickly and to build new strategic assets; the integration of these new strategic assets, including capability, technology and customer feedback, into company processes; and lastly the transformation or reuse of existing assets which have depreciated.<ref name="Teece et al."/><ref name="Eisenhardt and Martin">{{cite journal|last1= Eisenhardt|first1= Kathleen M.|last2= Martin|first2= Jeffrey A.|title=Dynamic capabilities:What are they? |url= http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/1097-0266%28200010/11%2921:10/11%3C1105::AID-SMJ133%3E3.0.CO;2-E/abstract |journal=Strategic Management Journal |volume= 21 |issue=10/11 |pages=1105–1122 |publisher=Wiley-Blackwell |date=October 2000|doi=10.1002/1097-0266(200010/11)21:10/11<1105::AID-SMJ133>3.0.CO;2-E |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref> Teece refers to successful implementation of these three stages as developing "corporate agility".<ref name="dynamic">{{cite journal|last=Teece|first=David J.|title=Explicating Dynamic Capabilities: The Nature and Microfoundations of (Sustainable) Enterprise Performance |url= http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/smj.640/abstract |journal=Strategic Management Journal |volume= 28 |issue=13 |pages=1319–1350 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |date=August 2007 |doi=10.1002/smj.640 |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref>
===Learning=== The first stage, learning, requires employees and managers to reorganize their routines to promote interactions that lead to successful solutions to particular problems, to recognize and avoid dysfunctional activity and strategic blind spots, and to make appropriate use of alliance and acquisition to bring new strategic assets into the firm from external sources. A practical example of this is provided by Jean-Pierre Jeannet and [[Hein Schreuder]], in their book ''From Coal to Biotech'', which lays out how the Dutch company [[DSM (company)|DSM]] transformed itself twice using 'strategic learning cycles'.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Jeannet |first1=Jean-Pierre |first2=Hein |last2=Schreuder |year=2015 |title=From Coal to Biotech: The transformation of DSM with business school support |publisher=Springer |isbn=9783662462980}}</ref>
=== New assets === In his 1988 book ''Managing Quality'', [[David A. Garvin]] states that quality performance depends on organisational routines for gathering and processing information, for linking customer experiences with engineering design choices and for coordinating factories and component suppliers.<ref name="Garvin1988">{{cite book|first=David A. |last=Garvin |title=Managing Quality: The Strategic and Competitive Edge|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K-LWY2qgSHwC|year=1988|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-02-911380-6|page=204}}</ref> Increasingly competitive advantage also requires the integration of external activities and technologies through alliances and partnerships.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zahra |first1=Shaker A. |last2=Nielsen |first2=Anders P. |title=Sources of capabilities, integration and technology commercialization |journal=Strategic Management Journal |date=1 May 2002 |volume=23 |issue=5 |pages=377–398 |doi=10.1002/smj.229 |url= http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/smj.229/abstract |issn=1097-0266 |accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref>
=== Transformation of existing assets === Economists Amit and Schoemaker pointed out in 1993 that success in fast changing markets depends on reconfiguring the firm’s asset structure to accomplish rapid internal and external transformation.<ref>{{cite book|last=Khalid |first=Saba |title=Exploring Firm Level Market Knowledge Competence and Its Implications for the Speed and Success of Export Expansion: A Mixed Methodology Study from the Software Industry|date=2009|publisher=University of Vaasa|isbn=9789524762700|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=afJT6sXTyroC&pg=PA25 |page=25|accessdate=7 December 2017}}</ref> Firms must develop processes to make changes inexpensively while accomplishing reconfiguration and transformation ahead of the competition. This can be supported by decentralization, local autonomy and strategic alliances.
===Co-specialization === Another "dynamic capabilities" concept is co-specialization. For example, the physical assets, human resources and the intellectual property of a company, having developed together over time, are more valuable in combination than separately, and give a firm a sustainable competitive advantage.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Douma |first1=Sytse |authorlink1=Sytse Douma |last2=Schreuder |first2=Hein |authorlink2=Hein Schreuder |title=Economic Approaches to Organisations |year=2013 |publisher=Pearson |isbn=9780273735298 |edition=Fifth |url= https://www.amazon.com/Economic-Approaches-Organisations-Sytse-Douma/dp/0273735292}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Corporate foresight]] * [[Resource-based view]] * [[Theory of the firm]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== * Arndt, Felix and Pierce, Lamar. 2017. The behavioral and evolutionary roots of dynamic capabilities. Industrial and Corporate Change. forthcoming. * {{cite journal | last1 = Barreto | first1 = Ilídio | year = 2010 | title = Dynamic Capabilities: A Review of Past Research and an Agenda for the Future | url = | journal = Journal of Management | volume = 36 | issue = 1| pages = 256–280 | doi=10.1177/0149206309350776}} * Ludwig, Gregory and Pemberton, Jon (2011). "A managerial perspective of dynamic capabilities in emerging markets: the case of the Russian steel industry", Journal of East European Management Studies, 16(3), pp. 215–236. ISSN 0949-6181 * Najda-Janoszka, Marta (2016). Dynamic capability-based approach to value appropriation. Krakow: Jagiellonian University Press.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dynamic Capabilities}} [[Category:Management]] [[Category:Organizational theory]]

revision.comment: changed Omnicomp to OmniComp
revision.text:
'''EnergyCAP''' is a family of [[energy management software|energy management]] and [[energy accounting software]] products, used for tracking, managing, processing, reporting, benchmarking, and analyzing utility bills and energy and sustainability information. EnergyCAP also interfaces with the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|EPA]] [[Energy Star]] Portfolio Manager. Multiple versions of EnergyCAP -- Enterprise, Express, and Professional -- are available to meet user functional requirements.
== History ==
EnergyCAP's history dates back to 1980. In response to a growing demand for energy management software when PCs were in their infancy, Steven D. Heinz founded OmniComp, Inc. in 1980 and launched the development of EnergyCAP predecessor FASER Energy Accounting.<ref>[http://www.energyeducation.com/NewsPress/tabid/63/newsid409/33/Default.aspx]</ref> FASER was first commercially released in 1982 for utility bill verification, tracking and reporting, and the calculation of the cost avoidance attributable to energy management activities (also called [[Measurement and Verification|Measurement & Verification]]). The City of Denver also uses this software to track energy usage throughout their parks system.
FASER became widely used by retail chains, government, universities, school districts and property managers. By the mid-1990s, FASER's thousands of users tracked an estimated five million bills a year valued at $2 billion. FASER and OmniComp were purchased by [[Enron|Enron Corporation]] in 1996.<ref>[http://people.ischool.berkeley.edu/~hal/footprint/10K/Enron-1998-10-K-d.htm]</ref> Following Enron's bankruptcy in late 2001, Heinz acquired the energy information assets<ref>[http://apps1.eere.energy.gov/buildings/tools_directory/software.cfm/ID=178/pagename=alpha_list]</ref> and launched Good Steward Software, which was renamed to EnergyCAP, Inc. in January 2010.<ref>[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/good-steward-software-announces-record-sales-in-2009-changes-name-to-energycap-inc-80720647.html]</ref> The team developed a new line of energy efficiency software products called EnergyCAP. EnergyCAP, Inc. is a five-time [[Energy Star]] Partner of the Year.
== Software Versions ==
EnergyCAP Enterprise is software for large organizations with comprehensive energy information management needs. Users include Fortune 1,000 companies; universities; military; and city, county, and state governments. EnergyCAP Express is utility bill and energy management software for small to medium-sized organizations like colleges, towns, and small- to medium-sized businesses. EnergyCAP Professional is oriented toward measurement and verification of energy savings for certain qualifying organizations, most notably school districts.<ref>[http://apps1.eere.energy.gov/buildings/tools_directory/software.cfm/ID=413/pagename=alpha_list]</ref>
== Software Features ==
EnergyCAP offers the following features: Account Tracking, [[Accounting software|Accounts Payable or G/L Export]], Bill Accruals, Bill Audits, Electronic Bills from Vendor, Energy Contract Administration, Issue Tracker, Workflow Management, Benchmarking Charts, Budgets & Forecasts, [[Measurement and Verification|Cost Avoidance (M&V)]], Energy Procurement, Rate/Tariff Analysis, Weather Data, Automated Report Distribution, Custom Spreadsheets for Data Export, Energy Dashboard, PowerViews, Reports, TreeView Navigation, Energy Star Benchmarking, [[Greenhouse gas|Greenhouse Gas Emissions]], Bill Splits, Move-In Utility Vacant Expense Recovery (MUVER), [[Utility submeter|Submeters]] & Chargebacks, Interval (Time-Series) Data, Meter Data Import, [[Microsoft SQL Server]], Unlimited Number of Users, Customizable User Permissions, Data Import Templates, Implementation Services, and Setup Wizards.
== Cost Avoidance ==
Cost Avoidance (Measurement & Verification) is the calculation of the savings attributable to energy management by comparing current bills with a normalized baseline year. The cost avoidance calculation engine of EnergyCAP complies with the [[International performance measurement and verification protocol]], the [[U.S. Department of Energy]]'s standard for energy performance measurement and verification. EnergyCAP adjusts for factors like changes in building square footage, type of primary use, billing period length, and weather.
== References == <references />
==External links== *[http://www.EnergyCAP.com EnergyCAP Official Website] *[http://www.eere.energy.gov/buildings/tools_directory/software.cfm/ID=412/pagename=alpha_list U.S. Dept of Energy's Building Technologies Program] *[http://www.evo-world.org Efficiency Valuation Organization] *[http://www.prweb.com/releases/2010/10/prweb4593474.htm Colorado Governor Mandates EnergyCAP for Sustainability Reporting] *[http://www.energyeducation.com/OurServices/YouMeasureSuccess/tabid/68/Default.aspx Energy Education Uses EnergyCAP for Savings Verification] *[http://www.prweb.com/releases/energycap/2010inc5000/prweb4423464.htm EnergyCAP Listed for Third Year in Inc. 5000]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Energycap}} [[Category:Business software]]
